S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

>ReST programming takes this evolution further.
>Where OOP created a relatively small number of
>object classes, ReST creates many.  Where OOP
>reduced the number of methods per object
>moderately, ReST reduces them drastically.
>Although we largely have been discussing ReST in
>terms of web architecture, there is no obvious
>reason why those design principles should not
>apply equally well within smaller scale
>programming contexts.

I am not sure if a reduced number of methods per object is beneficial 
for smaller scale programming contexts, but a programming context based 
on sending messages between resources (components) definitely is (see 
the links below).

>The transition to OOP resulted in new programming
>languages specifically designed to support that
>style of programming.  Is anyone working on a
>ReST Oriented Programming Environments?

In my opinion this theory comes close:

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~franz/pubs-pdf/C13.pdf

This one is a bit more specific, really good example code, but the pages 
seem to be scanned and are very hard to read, definitely worth a try though:

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~franz/pubs-pdf/J06.pdf

-- Erik
